alert.note: Alert for Coshocton (Ohio) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pittsburgh (Western Pennsylvania and East Central Ohio)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 23 at 10:47PM EST until February 28 at 5:00PM EST by NWS Pittsburgh
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio... Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County. Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County. .Previous and forecast rainfall will keep both Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville and the Muskingum River at Coshocton above flood stage through the weekend.
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at weather.gov/pbz. OHC031-241715- /O.EXT.KPBZ.FL.W.0009.000000T0000Z-220228T2200Z/ /CSHO1.1.ER.220218T0054Z.220225T1800Z.220228T1600Z.NO/ 1047 PM EST Wed Feb 23 2022 ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Muskingum River at Coshocton. * WHEN...Until Monday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 PM EST Wednesday the stage was 16.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 17.5 feet early Friday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late Monday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
